rows.n: Cf. {pa}, {no}, {moi}, {jatna}, {jemja'a}, {vairsoi}, {sozmoija'a}, {bivmoija'a}.  Based on STANAG 2116: NATO Codes for Grades of Military Personnel.
g: Marshal of the Indian Air Force
Marshal of the Royal Air Force

rows.d: number/quantity: 14 [fourteen].
marks a construct as figurative (non-literal/metaphorical) speech/text.
$x_1$ is a non-binary offspring/child of parent(s) $x_2$ [not necessarily biological]; $x_1$ is filial (but not a son or daughter).
rows.n: See discussion associated with "{dinti}" concerning whether this meaning is restricted to "affirmatively nonbinary" or whether it is more general. Umbrella term for any non-male, non-female (in some aspect/consideration/standard) child/offspring. Specifies "{selrirni}", "{verba}", "{panzi}" so as to be co-equal with "{bersa}" and "{tixnu}". See also: "{verba}", "{nanla}", "{nixli}", "{nakni}", "{fetsi}", "{dinti}", "{vepre}", "{nunmu}", "{patfu}", "{mamta}", "{rirni}", "{preri}", "{bruna}", "{mensi}", "{tunba}", "{pentu}", "{rorci}", "{panzi}", "{bersa}", "{tixnu}".

rows.d: $k_1$ is/are (a) dodecahedron(s)/dodecahedra/regular polyhedron [3-dimensional shape/form] and composed of twelve pentagonal sides $k_3$=$b_3$.
rows.n: See also dodecahedron (={pavrelbli}), not necessarily regular.

rows.d: $x_1$ is December/the twelfth month of year $x_2$ in calendar $x_3$.
$x_1$ is December/the twelfth month of year $x_2$ in calendar $x_3$.
$x_1$ happens once in interval $x_2$.
$x_1$ uses $x_2$ once, for purpose $x_3$
$x_1$ is a nonce (one-time use) lujvo used by $x_2$ for purpose $x_3$
rows.n: A {noi} clause can be added to x1 if desired.

rows.d: $pr_1$ is (a) monosexual/non-bisexual.
$c_1$ is monosexual in situation $c_2$ by standard $c_4$.
rows.n: Monosexual means sexual interest in only one sex/gender, so this word does not apply to bisexuals (= {relcinse}). Cf. {fetcinse}, {nakcinse}, {mitcinse}, {dutcinse}.

rows.d: $x_1$ is a one-time event/occurrence; $x_1$ does not happen again.
$x_1$ is a single-use/one-time tool/utensil/resource/implement used for doing $x_2$ (and discarded afterward).
rows.n: From {pavyfau} {tutci}. Synonyms: {pavyfauselpli}, {pavyplitci}. See also {festerplatci} 'disposable tool', {festerplakai} 'be disposable'.

rows.d: $x_1$=$v_1$=$f_1$ is a stage 1 fu'ivla meaning $x_2$=$v_2$, based on word $x_3$=$f_2$ in language $x_4$.
rows.n: 'stage 1 fu'ivla' is a term specific to Lojban and described in 'The Complete Lojban Language', chapter 4, section 7. The definition is similar to that of {fu'ivla}, but with the x3 place of {fu'ivla} omitted. x1 is assumed to be a Lojban quote including text of any language (see example) as the concept doesn't make much sense for other languages. See also {relfu'ivla} - 'stage 2 fu'ivla', {cibyfu'ivla} - 'stage 3 fu'ivla' and {vonfu'ivla} - 'stage 4 fu'ivla'

rows.d: $x_1$ (sound, text) is a monophthong.
$x_1$ is November/the eleventh month of year $x_2$ in calendar $x_3$.
$x_1$ is November/the eleventh month of year $x_2$ in calendar $x_3$.
$p_1$ is the closest planet (default is Mercury if p2 is the Sun) revolving around $p_2$ (default is the Sun), with planetary characteristics $p_3$, orbital parameters $p_4$.
$x_1$ a single-use tool/implement/implement for doing $x_2$; $x_1$ is designed to be discarded after the first use.
rows.n: From {pa} {pilno} {tutci}. Less ambiguous synonyms: {pavyfautci}, {pavyfauselpli}. Cf. {pavyplikai}/{pavyselplikai} 'be single use', {festerplatci} 'disposable tool', {festerplakai} 'disposable'.

rows.d: $p_1$=$s_1$ is alone, lacking the company of $s_2$.
$c_2$ believes in one god/deity $c_1$ with dominion over $c_3$; $c_2$ is a monotheist.
$j_2$ is a monopole with end $j_1$.
$x_1$ is a unicorn.
rows.n: Refers specifically to animals of the unicorn species, not the result of removing a horn from a two-horned animal.

rows.d: $x_1$ (si'o / proposed-or-existing cmavo) deserves a monosyllabic cmavo $x_2$, even though language $x_3$ (default Lojban) is running out of cmavo space, because of letteral-manipulation cmavo $x_4$ and other-rarely-used cmavo $x_5$, and it must have that monosyllabic cmavo at time $x_6$ (default: lo ca'abna), [insert expletive $x_7$ (default zo mabla)] it!
$x_1$ is a zygote / one-cell embryo of parent(s) $x_2$

$x1$ is the one(-like) element/multiplicative identity of structure/ring $x2$; often is denoted by  ' $1_R$ ' or  ' $I_R$  ' or by  (when context is obvious)  '1' or 'I', for structure/ring R (given by $x2$).
rows.n: Definition and rules may be specified in the second terbri; this definition does not suppose that the ring is not the 0-ring  (the trivial ring) with the mapping of all multiplications to 0 (in which case, the additive identity is also the multiplicative identity). The usage of "additive" and "multiplicative" in this context are defined by the ring. The nn identity matrix over a given ring is an example of one such element. See also: {nonsmi}

rows.d: $s_1$ is the single, unambiguous meaning of $s_2$ recognized/accepted by $s_3$; $x_2$=$s_2$ is unambiguous/explicit according to $x_3$=$s_3$.
$k_1$=$t_1$ is a quantity of/contains/is made of carbon monoxide (CO).
$t_1$ is monomorphic.
$x_1$ is a Monday evening of week $x_2$ in calendar $x_3$.
$x_1$ is a quantity of methanol from source $x_2$
$m_1$ is a unicycle/one-wheeled vehicle carrying $m_2$ in/on surface/medium $m_3$, propelled by $m_4$.
$k_1$ is $k_2$ (quantifier, default: one) potfuls in quantity.
$x_1$ is a scanner.
$x_1$ miscarries after being pregnant with $x_2$
$r_1$ has many children.
$x_1$ is a grandchild of $x_2$.
$x_1$ (individual, mass, or population (set?)) and $x_2$ (individual, mass, or population (set?)) are capable of mutually interbreeding/producing offspring with one another.
rows.n: This word is symmetric under exchange of $x_1$ with $x_2$ (conversion by "se"). $x_1$ need not be able to or actually fulfill the same roles in reproduction as $x_2$ or vice-versa; actual instances of reproduction need not occur/be realized. The standard for what constitutes ability to interbreed (is it just genetics? Do physiological/anatomical features restricting, say, gestation and successful birth matter? Must the populations actually know of one another?) is ambiguous and left unspecified.

rows.d: $x_1$ (set) is composed of members which interbreed with one another.
rows.n: This statement does not merely say that they *can* mutually interbreed, but that they *do*. It is uncertain whether it would be acceptable to use this word in reference to a set of cardinality greater than two in binary-sexed sexual species (for example: a set of two women and one man may be said to internally interbreed if the man breeds with each woman, but the women would be incapable of breeding with one another).

rows.d: $x_1$ is a part of Lojban text representing rule 'operator-1' according to the first edition of the book 'The Complete Lojban Language'.
rows.n: Inner structure of the rule: operator-2 | guhek operator-1 gik | operator-2 operator-2 (jek | joik) stag? BO # operator-1. For the description of the syntax see {jarnezi}.

rows.d: $x_1$ is a part of Lojban text representing rule 'text-1' according to the first edition of the book 'The Complete Lojban Language'.
rows.n: Inner structure of the rule: ((I (jek | joik)? (stag? BO)? #)+ | NIhO+ #)? paragraphs?. For the description of the syntax see {jarnezi}.

rows.d: $x_1$ is a part of Lojban text representing rule 'statement-1' according to the first edition of the book 'The Complete Lojban Language'.
rows.n: Inner structure of the rule: statement-2 (I joik-jek (statement-2)?)*. For the description of the syntax see {jarnezi}.

rows.d: $x_1$ is a part of Lojban text representing rule 'mex-1' according to the first edition of the book 'The Complete Lojban Language'.
rows.n: Inner structure of the rule: mex-2 (BIhE # operator mex-1)?. For the description of the syntax see {jarnezi}.

rows.d: $x_1$ is a part of Lojban text representing rule 'terms-1' according to the first edition of the book 'The Complete Lojban Language'.
rows.n: Inner structure of the rule: terms-2 (PEhE # joik-jek terms-2)*. For the description of the syntax see {jarnezi}.

rows.d: $x_1$ is a part of Lojban text representing rule 'sumti-tail-1' according to the first edition of the book 'The Complete Lojban Language'.
rows.n: Inner structure of the rule: quantifier? selbri (relative-clauses)? quantifier sumti. For the description of the syntax see {jarnezi}.

rows.d: $x_1$ is a part of Lojban text representing rule 'sumti-1' according to the first edition of the book 'The Complete Lojban Language'.
rows.n: Inner structure of the rule: sumti-2 ((ek | joik) stag? KE # sumti /KEhE#/)?. For the description of the syntax see {jarnezi}.

rows.d: $x_1$ is a part of Lojban text representing rule 'tanru-unit-1' according to the first edition of the book 'The Complete Lojban Language'.
rows.n: Inner structure of the rule: tanru-unit-2 linkargs?. For the description of the syntax see {jarnezi}.

rows.d: $x_1$ is a part of Lojban text representing rule 'selbri-1' according to the first edition of the book 'The Complete Lojban Language'.
rows.n: Inner structure of the rule: selbri-2 | NA # selbri. For the description of the syntax see {jarnezi}.

rows.d: $p_1$ is a double boiler/bain-marie containing $p_2$ made of $p_3$
Mercury.
number/quantity: 16 [sixteen].
number/quantity: 17 [seventeen].
$x_1$ is a part of Lojban text representing rule 'bridi-tail-1' according to the first edition of the book 'The Complete Lojban Language'.
rows.n: Inner structure of the rule: bridi-tail-2 (gihek # bridi-tail-2 tail-terms)*. For the description of the syntax see {jarnezi}.

rows.d: $x_1$ is a part of Lojban text representing rule 'operand-1' according to the first edition of the book 'The Complete Lojban Language'.
rows.n: Inner structure of the rule: operand-2 (joik-ek operand-2)*. For the description of the syntax see {jarnezi}.

rows.d: non-binary-gendered child
discursive: layperson/lac meaning;  marks a construct as layperson/common/non-technical/non-jargon speech/text
rows.n: Similar, but not equivalent, to {pe'a} and {sa'enai}.  If a construct could be interpreted in a technical sense (such as the word "likelihood" in English in the field of statistics) but is not being used in that technical sense, it may be marked for layperson interpretation by this word. See also: {pe'ainai}.

rows.d: technical meaning; marks a construct as jargon/terminology/technical/precise/exact speech/text
rows.n: Marks how a construct is to be interpreted/understood.  Similar, but not equivalent, to {pe'anai} and {sa'e}. If a construct should/could be interpreted in a technical sense (such as the word "likelihood" in English in the field of statistics) AND is actually being used in that technical sense (rather than in a layperson sense), it may be marked for technical interpretation by this word. See also: {pe'ai}

rows.d: literal sense; marks a construct as literal (non-figurative/non-metaphorical/exact) speech/text
rows.n: "Literally"; one sense of "exactly speaking".  Not to be used as an intensifier (unlike some usages of "literally" in English).

rows.d: $x_1$ is a figurative/metaphorical meaning of $x_2$ seen by $x_3$

weak metaphor marker: indicates that there is some broadening of the concept, typically to include objects of types that are unusual for the defined place structure, but which retains most of the semantic of the word as defined.
rows.n: See {pe'a}, {ru'e}, {do'a}. See the Lojban definitions for {dimnu'e} and {tcimi'e} for examples.

rows.d: $x_1$ is a text cursor (computer graphical element) of user interface $x_2$
restrictive relative phrase marker: permanently / inalienably associated with; it is impossible or near-impossible to break that relation
rows.n: Proposed as a variation of {po'e} with less semantic-boundary difficulties, while freeing up {po'e} for reassignment in dialects/forks. Most words that the concept of 'inalienable possession' applies to, e.g. {birka}, {mamta}, or even {pendo} in some natlangs, have a convenient {be} place to be used instead with a better-defined meaning. However, this may be used for any relation that is impossible-or-nigh-impossible to break, e.g. the car you worked on and made custom modifications to for years; in a sense, it will still be "your car" even if you sold it. {do'e}{cai} could be a variation to associate a bridi or the subject of the bridi, e.g. 'ti karce do'ecai mi'. See also {pesai}, {pe}

rows.d: $x_{1}$ is paper from source $x_{2}$.
rows.n: Sheet of paper (= {plekarda} if shape is important, {plebo'o}).  See also {karni}, {papri}, {prina}.

rows.d: $x_{1}$ is yellow/golden [color adjective].
$x_{1}$ is a poem/verse about plot/theme/subject/pattern $x_{2}$ by author $x_{3}$ for intended audience $x_{4}$.
rows.n: $x_2$ may be a convention rather than a subject.  See also {prosa}, {rimni}, {rilti}, {finti}, {lisri}, {sanga}.

rows.d: $x_{1}$ is a pen using ink $x_{2}$ applied by process $x_{3}$.
$x_{1}$ (agent) touches $x_{2}$ with $x_{3}$ [a locus on $x_{1}$ or an instrument] at $x_{4}$ [a locus on $x_{2}$].
$x_{1}$ is/acts as a friend of/to $x_{2}$ (experiencer); $x_{2}$ befriends $x_{1}$.
$x_{1}$ meets/encounters $x_{2}$ at/in location $x_{3}$.
$x_{1}$ thinks/considers/cogitates/reasons/is pensive about/reflects upon subject/concept $x_{2}$.
rows.n: Also: $x_1$ is thoughtful (one sense); $x_2$ is mental (one sense)/intellectual (one sense) (= {selpei}).  See also cmavo list {pe'i}, {jijnu}, {menli}, {morji}, {sidbo}, {jinvi}, se {nabmi}, {minra}, {lanli}, {besna}, {saske}, {skami}.

rows.d: $x_{1}$ is a pear [fruit] of species/strain $x_{2}$.

rows.n: $x_2$: composition including $x_2$, which need not be complete specification.  See also {marxa}, {kliti}, {tarla}.

rows.d: $x_{1}$ is $10^{15}$ of $x_{2}$ in dimension/aspect $x_{3}$ (default is units).
marks the following connective as joining termsets.
evidential: I opine (subjective claim).
attitudinal: attitudinal question; how do you feel about it? with what intensity?.
forethought flag for mathematical expression (mex) Polish (forethought) operator.
vocative: please.
$x_1$ is pink
$x_1$ is a non-binary sibling of/to $x_2$ by bond/tie/standard/parent(s) $x_3$; [not necessarily biological].
rows.n: See discussion associated with "{dinti}" concerning whether this meaning is restricted to "affirmatively nonbinary" or whether it is more general. See also: "{dinti}", "{nunmu}", "{tunba}", "{mensi}", "{bruna}", "{tamne}", "{famti}".

rows.d: $x_1$: its qualities are represented as a metaphor $x_2$ in dimension $x_{3+1,2}$
rows.n: $x_3$ can include references to $x_1$ and $x_2$. See {pe'a}, {sidysmu}, {tanru}, {metfo}, {ve} {lujvo}, {cimjvo}

rows.d: $x_1$ is pleasant to the touch / feels good to touch, to $x_2$

The feel/texture of $c_1$=$r_1$=$p_2$ is hair-raising/sets one's teeth on edge/squicks/gives the willies/heebie-jeebies to $p_1$, who touches it with $p_3$ [a locus on $p_1$ or an instrument] at $p_4$ [a locus on $c_1$=$r_1$=$p_2$].
rows.n: The unpleasant feeling induced is the same as that in {tinmosycpina}, but caused by touch rather than hearing.

rows.d: $v_1$ is a touchscreen serving function $v_2$.
$x_1$ feels friendly/fraternal love [philia] toward $x_2$
$x_1$ are friends (of each other, distributively)
rows.n: This is the {jvajvo} version of {simpe'o}. cf {pendo} and {simxu}

rows.d: $x_1$ is a friend of a friend of ... a friend of $x_2$ (experiencer), path-connected by the directed friendship relationship via intermediate nodes (friends) $x_3$ (list; ce'o).
rows.n: No friendship relation is necessarily symmetric. This word is a {brapagjvo} using {zevla} ".{utka}". Slightly shorter than "{pendy'utka}", which is semantically equivalent.
g: friend of a friend of a friend ...

rows.d: $x_1$ is a rule that can be used in a Parsing Expression Grammar (PEG)
rows.n: $x_1$'s first argument is the input text, its second argument is the parser's output, and its third one is the remainder of the text that the parser will process when done with this rule. Related: {pegyuenzi}, {peglfi}, {pegrsto}, {pegrpoi}, {pegnpe}, {pegnaka}, {pegrcu'a}, {pegrke'u}, {pegrsu'o}, {pegrsu'e}

rows.d: $x_1$ is a text matching PEG rule $x_3$, resulting in output $x_2$
$x_1$=$f_1$=$p_1$ is baffled/befuddled/perplexed/flummoxed by subject $x_2$=$p_2$; $x_1$=$f_1$=$p_1$ is stuck on problem $x_2$=$p_2$.
$pr_1$=$pe_1$ is an intellectual thinking thoughts/reflecting upon $pe_2$.
$p_1$=$c_1$ thinks thought $c_2$=$p_2$ (sedu'u/text/lu'e concept).
rows.n: Verbal or near-verbal expression of a thought; internal monologue.  Made from {pensi} + {cusku}.

rows.d: $x_1$=$p_1$ thinks back to origin/earlier state $x_3$ about $p_2$ (abstraction).
$g_1$ (agent) spreads $p_1$ over/into $p_2$ from $p_3$.
$x_1$ is Tuesday of week $x_2$ on calendar $x_3$.
$x_1$  is a yellow onion (Allium cepa) of variety/breed $x_2$.
$x_1$ is a lemon of variety $x_2$.
$j_1$ is made of/contains/is a quantity of lemon juice made from lemon/lemons $j_2$=$n_1$.
$x_1$ is lime [color adjective].
$x_1$ is an apricot [fruit] of species/variety $x_2$
$l_1$ is a American lotus/yellow lotus/water-chinquapin/vole, plant/flower/herb of species/strain $l_2$.
rows.n: The Linnaean binomial Nelumbo lutea (Willd.) is the currently recognized name for this species, which has been classified under the former names Nelumbium luteum and Nelumbo pentapetala, among others.

rows.n: The gismu {pelxu} refers to objects which are yellow, but not the color yellow itself.  This lujvo serves the latter purpose.  See also {skari} {zilska}

g: friend of a friend of a friend ...

$g_1$ is a group meeting showing common property $g_2$ at/in location $p_3$.
$x_1$ (set) meet at $x_2$ (location).
$x_1$ is a (so-called) science for socialization/matching/meeting between subjects $x_2$ in context/for purpose $x_3$, using methods $x_4$.

rows.n: Contraction of pensysku. This word does not follow the usual lujvo rules.

rows.d: $x_1$ feels friendship towards $x_2$
$p_1$=$m_1$ is a quantity of/is made of/contains pear wood/lumber of type $p_2$=$m_2$.
$t_1$ is a pear tomato of variety/strain $t_2$.

$p_1$=$k_1$ is considerate of $p_2$=$k_2$.
$x_1 =$ pr$_1$ is cognition (process of thought) with inputs $x_2 =$ pr$_2$, outputs $x_3 =$ pr$_3 =$ pe$_2$, passing through stages $x_4 =$ pr$_4$, performed by $x_5 =$ pe$_1$.
$s_1$=$p_1$ hypothesizes $s_2$=$p_2$ to audience $s_3$ about subject/concept $x_4$=$p_2$.

rows.d: $x_1$ is a "false friend" (word in different language that looks or sounds similar, but differs significantly in meaning) to $x_2$, meaning $x_3$ in language $x_4$.

rows.d: $l_1$ is an implicitly metaphorical lujvo with meaning $l_2$ and arguments $l_3$ built from metaphor $l_4$.

rows.d: $x_1$ is a coral of species $x_2$.
$x_1$ (organization/group/structure) is horizontal in metaphorical frame of reference $x_2$; $x_1$ lacks hierarchy/levels of membership of type $x_2$.

$x_1$ is a Freemason which belongs to lodge $x_2$, which belongs to grand lodge $x_3$.

rows.d: $u_1$=$pr_1$ is a combo box with text $c_2$ and list [ordered set] $po_1$ in user interface $u_2$.
rows.n: A combo box combines the capabilities of text fields (={ciska zei uidje}) and drop-down lists (={pejypoi zei uidje}). See also widget (={uidje}).

mark a logical connective as having maximal scope.
rows.n: Etymologically derived from {pe'e} but is in BAhE. When placed before a logical connective, makes it so that it is evaluated at the very end, so that it is not blocked by abstractions or sub-bridi. For example: "mi viska lo nanmu .i je mi viska lo ninmu" -> "mi viska lo nanmu .e lo ninmu" -> "mi viska lo nanmu pe'ei je ninmu", not "mi viska lo nanmu je ninmu".

rows.d: scalar / attitudinal question: how very...?
rows.n: Essentially asks for NAI/CAI. For selbri/sumtcita, the full range of NAI/CAI may be asked for; see http://mw.lojban.org/papri/zipcpi:_scalar_modifiers and {pai'e}. For attitudinals, it is limited to {ru'e}/{na'oi}/{sai}/{cai} or combinations thereof (use {pei} to ask for the full range).

rows.d: evidential question: how do you know that?
rows.n: Asks for UI2 (evidential) category, though a more detailed explanation may also be given.

rows.d: at-most-3-ary mekso operator: "integer exponent" for $X_1$ divided by $X_2$ in algebraic structure $X_3$
rows.n: Produces the maximum integer $n$ such that $X_2 ^n | X_1$ in/according to the rules of $X_3$. $X_1$ and $X_2$ each must be nonzero and not units. Context or explicit specification elsewhere may make $X_3$ unnecessary. For natural numbers, the Wolfram Language calls this "IntegerExponent" (if we ignore the arity and the default specifications; but the argument order is preserved). In this case ($X_3 = (N, +, *)$, where "$N $" denotes the set of all natural numbers (positive integers)), this function can be usefully restricted to $f:(N$ Exclude Set$(1))$ Union $P -> N$ Union Set$(0),$ $(r,p) -> $max$($ Set$(n$ in $N$ Union Set$(0): p^n$ divides $r$ in $N))$, where "P" denotes the set of primes in the unique factorization domain of integers.

rows.d: attitudinal category question: what is the category (UI4) of attitudinal?
rows.n: Specifically asks about the UI4-category, either when attached to attitudinals or used alone. Valid answers include both the category on its own and a whole UI with additional specifiers (as long as the category is included). Of course, any relevant -nai or -cu'i of the category must be included in the answer.

restrictive relative phrase marker: semi-permanently associated to; will remain associated unless something breaks that relation
rows.n: Proposed as a variation of {po} with less semantic-boundary difficulties, while freeing up {po} for reassignment in dialects/forks. Legal ownership is a possible relation; it could also mean, say, the chair assigned to you in an office, which will remain 'your' chair until reassigned, where mere {pe} could just mean the one you're sitting on. {do'e}{sai} could be a variation to associate a bridi or the subject of the bridi, e.g. 'ti stizu do'esai mi'. See {pecai}, {pe}, {ponse}, {po'a}
